posts.subject: Motivation

posts.body:
>>b79fce8b-df0d-4ab4-a89e-4c37585aa6d1
Hello, on the homepage i click unwanted board address and hide it. It seems it also mute board owner (it is one username that is muted). BUT when i refresh home page and scroll down to see "Recent posts", the unwanted board recent posts still appear there and when i accidentaly point my mouse pointer to the post from this board it loads bad images. It seems these images are from different user than one who was banned.

Is this something that can be improved so the unwanted/banned board is hidden also from "Recent posts"?

>>daac5a8e-b5f6-41d4-9d50-3c95fceefe6c
So when i clicked board owner ID and selected to mute him, it removed/hidden his board also? Because i do not see it. I thought i selected "Blacklist Board" option and i do not see the board, but i see new posts in ""Recent posts"" section on the index, as i mentioned, which seems wrong to me, because i accidentaly mouse over it and load bad images.

>>2ca44388-c78a-47f9-acac-54e6ae5d66b5
Thank you, i think i was confused by the difference between deleting/mutting user and the board. I think the user IDs in the board list is a confusing column and a bit redundant, because the option to mute user is already under Options menu that is opened when one click board name in the board list.
Currently it may give impression that when i try to click the string next to board name in the board list, it will "remove" the board. I see that when i mute user the board indeed has "???" name and its posts continue to appear in "Recent posts" section. When i Blacklist board, then it seems to be completely hidden including "Recent posts" which is good. I think removing the column with board owner IDs from the board list will get rid of a confusion between muting and banning and it will be more tidy/clean, because user mutting is already there in Options menu as mentioned.

"Privacy International is an organization based in the United Kingdom dedicated to protecting the privacy of citizens throughout the world. The organization is the recognized expert on privacy levels in dozens of countries, and its last major international survey ranked 49 nations based on how much privacy they gave to their citizens."

Countries in the Top 5 of the Privacy Index (best privacy protecting):

Greece
Canada
Romania
Hungary
Argentina

The Index was calculated based on a means score of 14 criteria, which included:

    Privacy enforcement

    Visual surveillance
    Communication interception
    Workplace monitoring

posts.subject: Size of the Universe and our place in it

posts.body: Flash app that allows to understand size of the objects on Earth and in Universe: [https://scaleofuniverse.com/](https://scaleofuniverse.com/)

posts.subject: Powers of Ten
posts.body: The Powers of Ten films are two short American documentary films written and directed by Charles and Ray Eames. Both works depict the relative scale of the Universe according to an order of magnitude (or logarithmic scale) based on a factor of ten, first expanding out from the Earth until the entire universe is surveyed, then reducing inward until a single atom and its quarks are observed.

posts.subject: Cosmic Voyage - zooming out into the edge of the observable universe
posts.body:
Cosmic Voyage is a 1996 short documentary film produced in the IMAX format, directed by Bayley Silleck, produced by Jeffrey Marvin, and narrated by Morgan Freeman.

Cosmic Voyage takes viewers on a journey through forty-two orders of magnitude, beginning at a celebration in Venice, Italy slowly zooming out into the edge of the observable universe. Then the view descends back to earth, and later zooms in upon a raindrop on a leaf on a hoop used in the celebration mentioned earlier, down to the level of subatomic particles (quarks).

In addition, the film offers some brief insight on the Big Bang theory, black holes, and the development of our Solar System. It also simulates a journey through Fermilab's Tevatron particle accelerator in Chicago, where an atom collision is depicted.

posts.subject: Cosmic Eye - Zooming from Earth to far galaxies and back into to atoms and quarks
posts.body: Cosmic Eye allows to user to zoom in and out of a preset image, by enormous zoom factors, reaching down the smallest known sub-atomic particles and up to the entire observable universe.

posts.subject: Routers
posts.body: discussion

posts.subject: Draytek Vigor 2925, 2926 advanced traffic routing
posts.body:
Router Draytek Vigor 2925, 2926... allows advanced routing of the traffic thru multiple WAN ports and a VPN server of choice based on source/destination IP, protocol, port numbers.

If anyone interested, here is how it is done, explained by the Draytek support staff:
"
Open the demo interface of the v2926 available here http://eu.draytek.com:12926/
In the [Routing >> Load-Balance/Route Policy] section, click on profile 1 (index 1). A new page should appear (note that settings can't be saved on this demo interface).
This is where your LAN PC source IP can be defined. I have attached the setup example (Capture.PNG) where http traffic (port 80) will be routed through VPN1 interface. Note that failover option is also available.

There is an article describing this feature, available for registered users: https://www.draytek.co.uk/support/guides/kb-policy-routing-guide-v2
Also, our UK based support team can assist you (it is free!) by email or phone: https://www.draytek.co.uk/support/contact-support
"

- If you are planning to connect to remote VPN servers run by companies such as NordVPN etc., please make sure that they VPN tunnel requirements can be matched/are available on DrayTek or other vendors' router.
The setup for this might be similar to the above. 
1) Make sure that the VPN is established with the VPN provider.
2) Local PC is set with a static IP address
3) Route Policy similar to the attached is enabled on the router.


PS: [Here is](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1527007067_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Dual+WAN+routers+for+internet+connectivity+load+balancing+failover) the NetTalk thread about dual WAN routers. Routers with the LTE failover.

posts.subject: What is seeding, how to help distribute content of some user, how PINning works
posts.body:
How seeding and PINning currently (2/2020) works on Millchan. This is what i discovered during my testing.

seeding = texts of this website are always downloaded, but images, videos etc. are optional. You can select to seed these optional files which will download it so you can quickly view it and ZN will automatically distribute/upload it to other people

PINning = mark some board and all its optional files (images, videos etc.) the way that ZN will not delete these in case you are exhausting yours defined quota for optional files - seen and defined on site [ZeroHello/?Files](/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D/?Files) - ZN should feature some garbage collector which automatically deletes files with high peer count in case you are out of space.

. . . . . . .

PINning:

On the homepage when you click the button next to the board and PIN it, all optional files (existing and future) gets PINned. By optional files here we mean images, videos and similar. When you select unPIN menu option, all files gets unPINned.
No other onsite action seems to be PINning the files.

1. Download all content (images, videos...) of a user:
not possible. you have to download and distribute all users content - discouraged, there are illegal images too (right corner button drag & drop to the left)

2. Auto-download all FUTURE content (images, videos...)  of a user:
click arrow next to the post of the user and click to Help seed files.

3. Download all content (images, videos...) of a discussion board (not talking about topic):
On the homepage when you click the button next to the board you can select to Download small and big files.

posts.subject: Solution
posts.body:
On the server,
Enable IP forwarding in /etc/sysctl.conf on server: net.ipv4.ip_forward=1
Execute following for the changes to take effect: sysctl -p

On the server, add iptables firewall rules (read the description below to adjust the commands):
iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o venet0 -j MASQUERADE
iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -i venet0 -p tcp --dport 1234 -j DNAT --to 10.8.0.2:1234

1234 - port to open, properly forward its connections into the tunnel. Range can be defined like this: --dport 1234:1240 and the "--to" would miss the port and only IP possibly.
10.8.0.2 - local IP address of the OpenVPN client network interface/adapter (shown by the OpenVPN client software and also in "ipconfig" Windows command output)
venet0 - Linux server network interface name (usually one with most traffic reported by "ifconfig" command, often "eth0")
tcp - connection type. there is also for example "udp", it may be needed to add one more rule separately for udp if is needed

If added wrong rule, you may delete rule for example: iptables -t nat -D POSTROUTING RuleNumber (number discovered by command "service iptables status")

On the VPN client, allow INcoming connections made to that port 1234

Try if port is open:
https://www.ecosia.org/search?q=open+port+check

Try disabling firewall. If port is opened, do not forget to save server iptables rules to survive reboot. [related topic](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1520435905_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Do+i+need+to+setup+custom+port+forwarding+on+a+VPN+server+to+have+custom+port+open)

Related topic: [Some popular MS Windows software and its Linux alternatives](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1579103005_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS)

Shareaza alternative:
Gtk-Gnutella
quazzaa?
fopnu

posts.subject: Basic/beginner Linux iptables firewall commands
posts.body:
Note: This is not meant to be complete set of the Linux iptables commands

iptables is a tool to manage Linux firewall. Some distributions though use other tools like a ufw tool.

BASIC IMPORTANT COMMANDS

- Commands to output/list current firewall configuration:

service iptables status
iptables-save (the rules are output the way that it can be easily prefixed by "iptables " and used as a commands)
iptables -L

- Firewall chains and its policy

Topmost rules in the chain has a higher priority which means it will override lower rules.
The firewall has several chains like an INPUT, FORWARD, OUTPUT and each chain has set default policy (ACCEPT, DROP, REJECT)
For example if i want maximum protection, i only add rules for particular ports and set REJECT policy which will cause all other connections be rejected.

- Make a backup of the iptables configuration

iptables-save > /etc/sysconfig/iptables_1.2.2020

- Save current rules to be used on next boot (if you are sure your rules are correct)

service iptables save
iptables-save > /etc/sysconfig/iptables (if previous doest not work this one MAY work)

- delete iptables rule

1. list and discover rule number from each line prefix
a) iptables -L
b) iptables -L INPUT --line-numbers
c) service iptables status

2. delete
iptables -D INPUT 5 (delete rule at 5th line of the INPUT chain)

- add/prepend iptables rule

iptables -I INPUT -s 1.2.3.4 -j DROP (add new rule to the first line of INPUT chain to ignore connections from IP 1.2.3.4)

- add/append iptables rule

iptables -A INPUT -s 1.2.3.4 -p tcp --dport 80 -j REJECT (add new rule to the last line of INPUT chain to reject connections from IP 1.2.3.4 port 80 and protocol TCP)

- set chain policy (for example ACCEPT policy means that all connections that does not match any rule are accepted)

iptables -P FORWARD ACCEPT (this time for the FORWARD chain, other option is INPUT and OUTPUT)

- connections logging enable (disable can be done by replacing -I by -D. Do not forget to disable to not fill your logs)

iptables -I INPUT -j LOG (log connections on the INPUT into system log (/var/log/syslog or /var/log/messages usually)

- delete all iptables rules (flush)

iptables -F
(note that on next boot, it can restore rules from /etc/sysconfig/iptables or such similar file. Location of the file by command: locate iptables)
Hi, when i copy a URL of the focused image (mouse right click), it is a base64 URI now. There was some change to improve the site design or it is just my web browser Firefox?

I was having same problem, maybe with other board, i would think it is some bug in zeronet.
i think that it can be solved by opening this site menu (drag & drop top-right corner button to the left), scroll down and click button to reload and rebuild database (db). Then refresh the page. Maybe it will help. This issues bother me, but i do not know how the cause can be debug so the developer can fix it...

posts.subject: over 1,000 metric tons of microplastic fall on 11 protected areas in the US annually
posts.body:
researchers report a startling discovery: After collecting rainwater and air samples for 14 months, they calculated that over 1,000 metric tons of microplastic particles fall into 11 protected areas in the western US each year. Thatâ€™s the equivalent of over 120 million plastic water bottles. â€œWe just did that for the area of protected areas in the West, which is only 6 percent of the total US area,â€ says lead author Janice Brahney, an environmental scientist at Utah State University. â€œThe number was just so large, it's shocking.â€
https://www.wired.com/story/plastic-rain-is-the-new-acid-rain/

"Deposition rates averaged 132 plastics per square meter per day, which amounts to >1000 metric tons of plastic deposition to western U.S. protected lands annually."
https://science.sciencemag.org/content/368/6496/1257

posts.subject: Love and the value of the human being
posts.body: It looks to me that it is more beneficial/valuable to love someone who feels no love and care than to give love and attention to people who already receive it from others. I read that the life without love has no meaning. Maybe most valuable person that actually benefits the society is the one that pays attention for the people that lack the attention/love/happiness.

posts.subject: Feature request (hide sticky topic)
posts.body:
@mcdev often it is not handy to see the sticky topic and its replies always on top. You already read it X times. In the default thread view it is always on top including its comments and one have to scroll way down to find interesting content.
SOLUTION: add new menu entry to the sticky topic menu (that arrow button) "Hide this topic and its replies". Unsure if necessary, but maybe the confirmation popup can mention file name to edit so user knows where to revert the operation.

posts.subject: Comparison of Environmental Impact of Plastic, Paper and Cloth Bags
posts.body:
[Comparison of Environmental Impact of Plastic, Paper and Cloth Bags](http://www.niassembly.gov.uk/globalassets/documents/raise/publications/2011/environment/3611.pdf)

quoting:

"The report set out to find out which of seven types of bags have the lowest environmental impact by assessing pollution caused by extraction of raw materials, production, transportation and disposal.  It found that an HDPE plastic bag would have a baseline global warming potential of 1.57 kg Co2 equivalent, falling to 1.4 kg Co2e if re-used once, the same as a paper bag used four times (1.38 kg Co2e).  A cotton bag would have to be re-used 171 times to emit a similar level, 1.57 kg Co2e."

"So which bag should you use? All bags have an impact. The best solution would be to use a cotton bag several hundred times, probably using it constantly for years. If you are not going to do that, a plastic bag â€“ re-used as a bin liner â€“ is the next best option, better than paper. Avoid accepting a plastic bag unless you need one, though"

posts.subject: Install torrent client with a webUI on headless Linux
posts.body:
Possibly most popular and best open source torrent client qBittorrent can be run on headless Linux (no monitor, no X available).
+ it has Web user interface (WebUI) built in. Setup was incredibly easy.

CentOS Linux: yum install epel-release;yum update;yum install qbittorrent-nox;qbittorrent-nox --webui-port=8080
Ubuntu(Debian?) Linux: sudo add-apt-repository ppa:qbittorrent-team/qbittorrent-stable;sudo apt update && sudo apt install qbittorrent-nox
This article mentions how to setup the service/auto-start on Ubuntu, but you may try possibly a bit easier way described below.

Daemon mode (task runs on background): add "-d" switch to the command

Run at Linux startup (tested on CentOS): echo "@reboot root qbittorrent-nox -d --webui-port=8080" > /etc/cron.d/qbt;chmod 600 /etc/cron.d/qbt
Cronjob can be also added to "crontab -e"

posts.subject: BTC 2021 electricity consumption / CO2 emissions per transaction
posts.body:
Bitcoin electricity consumption & CO2 emissions from multiple sources:

1) 2021 https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/how-much-energy-does-bitcoin-really-consume-2021-05-13
As of mid-May, electricity demand for bitcoin is hovering around 143 terawatt-hours, significantly outpacing electricity consumption of several countries including Argentina.

2) 2021 https://hbr.org/2021/05/how-much-energy-does-bitcoin-actually-consume
According to the Cambridge Center for Alternative Finance (CCAF), Bitcoin currently consumes around 110 Terawatt Hours per year

3) 2021 https://digiconomist.net/bitcoin-energy-consumption
Annualized ... Carbon Footprint 58.23 Mt CO2 ... Electrical Energy 122.59 TWh | Single Bitcoin Transaction Footprints ... Carbon Footprint 664.68 kgCO2 ... Electrical Energy 1399.32 kWh

4) 2019 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S2214629620302966?via%3Dihub
We conservatively estimate the Bitcoin network to consume 87.1 TWh of electrical energy annually per September 30, 2019

5) 2019 https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/06/190613104533.htm
Source: Technical University of Munich (TUM) ... The use of Bitcoin causes around 22 megatons in carbon dioxide emissions annually

6) 2021 https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-01-26/is-bitcoin-mining-worth-the-environmental-cost
estimated carbon footprint would be comparable to New Zealand at about 37 million tons of carbon dioxide. ... Bitcoinâ€™s annual consumption is estimated at around 77.8 terawatt-hours, up from 9.6 terawatt-hours in 2017, according to Digiconomist. Another index, compiled by the Cambridge Center for Alternative Finance, estimates a higher figure of around 108.4 terawatt-hours.

So, what is the average electricity consumption?
To count average, i sum up all the above estimates and divide the sum by number of estimates: 143+110+122+87(y.2019)+77+108=647/6=107
So the BTC annual electricity consumption (we are not considering manufacturing of mining equipment) is around 107TWh annually.

Average CO2 emissions/year?
Sum up megaton values claimed above and divide it to get average: 58+22(2019)+37=117/3=39
39 Mt (39 000 000 tons) of CO2 annually. Daily it is 39 000 000/365=106 849 tons daily ðŸ˜®. Now divide by daily number of BTC transactions:
https://www.blockchain.com/explorer/
https://bitinfocharts.com/comparison/bitcoin-transactions.html
(it seems that for the past 4 years, average is roughly at 260 000 tx/day), 106849/260000=0,41 tons per transaction (410kg of the CO2 greenhouse gas to process single payment...â—ï¸)

To count CO2 out of electricity used, one have to know where miners are located and which way their electricity is generated (electricity mix and CO2 produced per the energy source. It is said 60% in china, partly powered by cheap hydro electricity. https://www.sunearthtools.com/tools/CO2-emissions-calculator.php#txtCO2_5 shows old figures, but if i take France (green electricity country powered by nuclear as an average for BTC), the figure is footprint 79g CO2/kWh.. maybe some CO2 Mt number can be obtained from that knowing 107 tWh/year BTC figure.

posts.subject: 800 million people in the world are hungry
posts.body:
"Today, more than 800 million people in the world are hungry, two billion people are suffering from micronutrient deficiencies and 2 billion people are overweight or obese. But these groups are not necessarily distinct; not all malnutrition is the result of food insufficiency. So when we consider food as a component of global health, it is not just a matter of quantity."

"The world already produces enough food to feed everyone on the planet. But, as a recent UNEP report found, over 17 per cent of food is wasted."

https://www.unep.org/news-and-stories/story/food-systems-hold-key-ending-world-hunger
[Impressive visualisation of the past and present CO2 emissions by NASA!](https://climate.nasa.gov/news/3020/how-much-carbon-dioxide-are-we-emitting/)

posts.subject: Testimony of Historians that Jesus walked the Earth
posts.body:
Testimony of Historians

For instance, consider the testimony of Flavius Josephus, a first-century Jewish historian who was a Pharisee. He referred to Jesus Christ in the book Jewish Antiquities. Although some doubt the authenticity of the first reference where Josephus mentioned Jesus as the Messiah, Professor Louis H. Feldman of Yeshiva University says that few have doubted the genuineness of the second reference. There Josephus said: â€œ[Ananus the high priest] convened the judges of the Sanhedrin and brought before them a man named James, the brother of Jesus who was called the Christ.â€ (Jewish Antiquities, XX, 200) Yes, a Pharisee, a member of the sect many of whose adherents were avowed enemies of Jesus, acknowledged the existence of â€œJames, the brother of Jesus.â€

The influence of Jesusâ€™ existence was felt through the activities of his followers. When the apostle Paul was imprisoned in Rome about 59 C.E., the principal men of the Jews told him: â€œAs regards this sect it is known to us that everywhere it is spoken against.â€ (Acts 28:17-22) They called Jesusâ€™ disciples â€œthis sect.â€ If they were everywhere spoken against, secular historians would likely report about them, would they not?

Tacitus, born about 55 C.E. and considered one of the worldâ€™s greatest historians, mentioned the Christians in his Annals. In the account about Neroâ€™s blaming the great fire of Rome in 64 C.E. on them, he wrote: â€œNero fastened the guilt and inflicted the most exquisite tortures on a class hated for their abominations, called Christians by the populace. Christus, from whom the name had its origin, suffered the extreme penalty during the reign of Tiberius at the hands of one of our procurators, Pontius Pilatus.â€ The details of this account match the information regarding the Jesus of the Bible.

Another writer who commented on Jesusâ€™ followers was Pliny the Younger, the governor of Bithynia. In about the year 111 C.E., Pliny wrote to Emperor Trajan, asking how to handle Christians. People who were falsely accused of being Christians, wrote Pliny, would repeat an invocation to the gods and worship the statue of Trajan, just to prove that they were not Christians. Pliny continued: â€œThere is no forcing, it is said, those who are really Christians, into any of these compliances.â€ That testifies to the reality of the existence of the Christ, whose followers were prepared to give their lives for their belief in him.

After summarizing the references to Jesus Christ and his followers by the historians of  the first two centuries, The EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica (2002 edition) concludes: â€œThese independent accounts prove that in ancient times even the opponents of Christianity never doubted the historicity of Jesus, which was disputed for the first time and on inadequate grounds at the end of the 18th, during the 19th, and at the beginning of the 20th centuries.â€
